data.title: Japanese Collection: Asian Collections at the Library of Congress
data.meta_description: The Library’s Japanese collection comprises more than 1.2 million physical items. This guide provides an overview of these materials, outlines search strategies, and describes how to access digital collections and e-resources. Japanese Electronic Resources available at the Asian Division, Library of Congress
data.text:
Japanese American Service Committee Legacy Center Archives External This link opens in a new window

Founded on August 30, 1946, the Japanese American Service Committee of Chicago (JASC) originally served the needs of the Issei and Nisei (Japanese immigrants and their American-born children) that left World War II internment camps to resettle in Chicago and start new lives. Today, JASC maintains an archive of Japanese American life in Chicago. The Legacy Center Archives document all facets of Japanese American life from 1890, through the period of World War II internment and on to the present day. It is one of the most significant collections of Japanese American history, arts and cultural materials in the Midwest. Seeking to engage people of all ages to experience Japanese American history and culture as part of the multicultural community in the United States, the Legacy Center aims to raise public awareness of the archives and expand access for genealogical scholars, academics, educators and the general public.

Kusuda Collection Online External This link opens in a new window

This archive contains the papers of Minoru Kusudu (1964-2003), secretary and advisor of Prime Minister Eisaku Sato (1902-1975), the longest-serving prime minister of postwar Japan (1964-1972), the longest of any Japanese PM since the end of World War II. The collection includes:

Part I includes primary documents from the highest level of government of the Sato Administration, including a number of documents classified as Top Secret or higher and documents pertaining to Japan-U.S. security relations, in particular the presence of U.S. military forces on the island of Okinawa.

Part II begins with the Kishi and Ikeda administrations, which preceded the appointment of Kusuda as chief secretary, and continues with various documents from the Sato administration as addenda to Part I. This collection fills in the gaps in the archives of Japanese politics from the late 1970s to the early 1990s.

Meiji Japan External This link opens in a new window

This database provides virtual access to the Edward Sylvester Morse Collection from the Phillips Library at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Massachusetts. Edward Sylvester Morse (1838-1925) was a polymath notable for his work in natural history, ethnography and art history and was one of the first American scientists to work extensively in Japan. His collection of Japanese art and artifacts contributed to the early study and appreciation of Japanese culture in the United States. His personal and professional papers, available through this database, feature rare and ephemeral material on a variety of subjects, including archaeology, art, astronomy, ethnology, religion and zoology, as well as writings that shed light on his desire to encourage the appreciation of Asian culture among an American audience.

Asahi Shinbun Cross-search External This link opens in a new window

This database l contains 13 million articles and advertisements published by the Asahi newspaper since its first issue in 1879. The database also includes regional versions of the Asahi newspaper, two weekly magazines (AERA and Weekly Asahi), a pictorial magazine (Asahi Graph), and a contemporary Japanese dictionary (??? - Chiezo) which has been published annually. Also includes a Japanese version of Who's Who and an historical photo archive. More than 1,000 articles are added to the database on a daily basis. User Guide: http://database.asahi.com/library2e/main/help/help.html

The simultaneous user limit for this resource may result in temporary delays. Click LOGIN to enter the database; username and password are not necessary.

Japan Chronicle External This link opens in a new window

The English-language Kobe Chronicle Weekly (1900-1941), and Japan Chronicle Daily (1929-1940) are the newspapers of record for Japans engagement with modernity and its emergence, through war, political and social upheaval and seismic social change in East Asia, onto the world stage in the first half of the twentieth century. Historians of East Asia have long seen the Japan Chronicle as a uniquely valuable resource. This well-informed, controversial but always readable source of news and opinion on Japan and East Asia offers an intriguing and lively Japanese complement to the North-China Herald (current coverage of the full-text database, 1900-1941).

Japanese-American Internment Camp Newspapers, 1942 to 1946 This link opens in a new window

Produced by the Japanese-Americans interned at assembly centers and relocation centers around the country during World War II, these newspapers provide a unique look into the daily lives of the people who were held in these camps. They include articles written in English and Japanese, typed, handwritten and drawn. They advertise community events, provide logistical information about the camps and relocation, report on news from the community, and include editorials. Included in this collection are 4600+ issues of 29 newspaper titles (in English, Japanese, or both) from camps in seven states.

Japan Times Archive External This link opens in a new window

Japan Times Ltd., founded in 1897, publishes Japans oldest English language newspaper. Today, the Japan Times is the countrys only independent English-language newspaper. In it readers will find the latest news and features from Japan: business, politics, commentary, culture, lifestyle, entertainment and sports. The Archive commences with no. 1 of the Japan Times (March 22, 1897) and covers The Japan Times & Mail (April 2, 1918-Nov. 10, 1940), the Japan Times and Advertiser (Nov. 11, 1940-Dec. 31, 1942), the Nippon Times (Jan. 1, 1943-June 30, 1956), Japan Times "Bakumatsu Period Online Edition" (September 1865-June 1866), Japan Times (March 22, 1897-), and the Japan Times (July 1, 1956 onwards).

Maisaku (Mainichi Shimbun) External This link opens in a new window

The Mainichi Shimbun 毎⽇新聞 (“Daily News”) is the oldest existing Japanese daily newspaper with a history spanning over 140 years. During the transformative years of the Meiji era (1868-1912), two newspapers were established: the Tokyo Nichi Nichi Shimbun 東京日日新聞, in 1872, and the Osaka Nippo大阪日報, in 1876. The two papers merged in 1911 and were placed under the Mainichi Shimbun masthead in 1943. The "Maisaku" database provides access to over 6 million articles from Tokyo Nichi Nichi Shimbun, Osaka Nippo, and Mainichi Shimbun from 1872 to the present and from the Mainichi Weekly Economist from 1989 to the present. In addition, users gain access to the following supplementary content: The Mainichi (English-language publication of MS, June 2008- present); Mainichi Opinion Polls (Mainichi Yoron Sāchi, more than 360 polls conducted since 1945 from the only newspaper poll database in Japan); “2,001 Major Events of the 20th Century” (a selection of over 2,000 major events, as described in series of articles published by MS over 100 years); and a history of the development of Mainichi Shimbun as a publication and a company.

The simultaneous user limit for this resource may result in temporary delays.

Nikkei Telecom21 External This link opens in a new window

The database focuses on Japan-related matters containing the following:

News Flashes - Approximately 1000 news flashes per day virtually in real-time.

Article Archive Search - 500-200 articles updated per day. Backfile goes as far back as 1876. Sources include major business and financial newspapers published by Nikkei such as the Nikkei and Nikkei Business Daily.

Corporate Profiles - Data compiled for over 20,000 Japanese firms including basic corporate information and financial data.

People Search - Data available for more than 200,000 corporate executives, politicians and government officials in Japan.

Main language of this database is Japanese. News Flashes and Article Archive Search are also available in English. Sources of the database are reliable Nikkei sources.

Rafu Shimpo External This link opens in a new window

Rafu Shimpo is the longest running Japanese American newspaper in the United States. The paper began in 1903 supporting the small but growing Japanese community in the Little Tokyo area of Los Angeles, California. By the 1940s it was the most widely circulated paper in the region and included a weekly English section for second generation Japanese Americans. Rafu Shimpo was completely suspended from 1942-1945, and no issues were produced. The Rafu Shimpo Digital Archive contains all obtainable published issues from 1914 through 2017. Included is an institutional subscription to rafu.com that allows for full access to the present day. The archive will grow with additional years’ worth of content added annually.

Sports Industry History Database External This link opens in a new window

The Sports Industry History Database is a full-text database of the first sporting good trade newspaper in Japan, which started its publication in 1948. It is essentially the ONLY specialized newspaper resource available to study the development of sports, the sports industry, and sporting goods trade in Japan. In addition, this archival collection is not held at any institutions or libraries, including the National Diet Library, Japan; it is only available from the publisher of the newspaper itself. The full-text contents includes 900 issues of this newspaper and be searched by keywords.

Yomidas Rekishikan External This link opens in a new window

Yomidas Rekishikan is an online database of over 11 million articles from every issue of Japans most trusted newspaper, Yomiuri Shimbun, since its first issue in 1874. The database has four parts: 1) the Meiji, Taisho and Showa Eras section (1874-1989), containing scans of the articles as they appeared in the original print editions 2) the Heisei Era section (September 1986 onwards), presenting articles in a text view, as well as a clipping view of the original article (December 2008 onwards) 3) the Daily Yomiuri section (September 1989 onwards), cataloging articles which have appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbuns English publication and 4) the Contemporary Whos Who, with searchable biographical data on over 26,000 prominent individuals as well as articles which pertain to them. Yomidas Rekishikan offers search pages and a Help section in English, to help find news articles of interest and explain the features of the database. As a further aid to non-Japanese, recent articles in the Japanese (Heisei era) and the English (Daily Yomiuri) editions are linked to each other to allow easy switching between the two versions of the article. Includes the full text of the Yomiuri Shinbun, from its initial publication in 1874 to date, as well as full text of the Daily Yomiuri, its English language equivalent, and a biographical dictionary of modern Japanese figures. Articles are keyword indexed and can be searched full-text.

Bungei Shunju Archives External This link opens in a new window

“Bungei Shunju Archives” covers the first 25 years (1923-1950) of "Bungei Shunju," a monthly magazine established by Kikuchi Kan (1888-1948), a distinguished author, playwright, and editor. Over its first several years, the magazine mainly featured literary works and essays by novelists, many of whom gained prominence as leading writers of 20th-century Japan. KBooks Bungeishunju Archives consists of a full collection of all 323 issues of Bungeishunju from the first issue to December 1950 (excluding special issues). Around 90,000 pages of the original magazine are available in PDF format, and you can do full-text searches.

Toyo Keizai Shimpo External This link opens in a new window

This digital collection contains a complete set of 5,800 issues spanning the years 1895 to 2015 for Tōyō keizai shinpō 東洋経済新報 / Shūkan Tōyō Keizai 週刋東洋経済, one of Japan's leading magazines devoted to economic and business news. Topics covered by this periodical also extend to politics, diplomacy, contemporary social issues, and the media, among others. Issues from 1995 and earlier can be searched by terms found in the title of an article or an author’s name. Issues from 1996 and later, meanwhile, feature full-text searching.

eol AsiaOne External This link opens in a new window

The eol AsiaOne database provides detailed information on corporate Japan and the East Asia region, including company and management profiles, annual reports, publicly filed financial and compliance documents, and press releases. It contains data on every publicly-traded company (over 4,000 in Japan and approx. 6000 in East Asia) and on private, unlisted companies (approximately 1,900) from 1984 to the present. The database is updated daily. Actual financial data can be downloaded. Available in both Japanese and English interfaces.

Select "Automatic login." The simultaneous user limit for this resource may result in temporary delays.

MagazinePlus External This link opens in a new window

Japanese index to over 4 million articles in 8,500 journals and magazines covering medicine, science, law, humanities, popular culture, business and social sciences. Magazineplus also indexes about 6,000 annual reports and collections of academic articles ( ronbunshu ) published by Japanese academic institutions. ?MagazinePlus is the largest multi-disciplinary indexing database of academic periodicals and articles in Japan, covering 8,500 scholarly journals in various fields and general interest periodical titles, and providing bibliographical references to 4,850,000 articles from 1975 to the present. It also includes bibliographic information for 6,000 reports, theses, and articles in the areas of humanities and social science published by Japanese academic institutions. Periodicals indexed include scholarly titles from the National Diet Library's Zasshi kiji sakuin (1975- ) popular magazines indexed in Ja?naru indekkesu (1981- ) 1300 Japanese economic and business magazines (1981-1995) and 60 overseas business magazines (1984- ). Festchrifte (1945-2003), symposia and speeches (1945-2003), bulletins, transactions, conference proceedings (1945-2002) are also included. Areas covered include the humanities, social sciences, and science and technology.
